Graphical abstract A novel efficient and recyclable PEG1000-D(A)IL/toluene temperature driven reversible biphasic system was developed and applied in esterification of aromatic acids and acetalization of aromatic aldehydes in good to excellent yields. A novel efficient and recyclable temperature-dependent biphasic catalyst and reaction media combined system comprised of PEG-1000 linked dicationic acidic ionic liquid and toluene was developed and applied in esterification of aromatic acids and acetalization of aromatic aldehydes with good to excellent yields. This system is characteristic of temperature-dependent reversible biphasic property, simple and facile recyclability, high catalytic activity and extensive substrate and reaction adaptability. Keywords Poly(ethylene glycol) Ionic liquids Thermoregulated Esterification Acetalization 1 Introduction It is well known that homogeneous catalysis has the remarkable advantage of the ability to fully show the catalytic activity in reaction but unfortunately accompanying with the obvious drawback of laborious separation and recycling of catalyst. Immobilization of catalyst on solid “stationary” supports is a common way to make sure of catalyst recovery [1,2]. However, this kind of heterogeneous catalysis shows reduced catalytic activity. To complement each other's advantages, chemists have been making their best efforts and found some protocols. Temperature-dependent reversible biphasic reaction is one of the important area for recyclable catalysis. Aqueous/organic biphasic system has attracted attentions for long time. In this kind of system, catalyst locates in a “mobile phase” [3,4]. It is generally believed that the reaction takes place in the aqueous phase or at the phase boundary. After the completion of reaction, a simple phase-separating operation could lead the catalyst and product to be separated. But aqueous/organic biphasic system is not suitable for water-sensitive reactions. To solve this problem, a variety of approaches have been attempted, such as “fluorous biphasic system (FBS)” [5–8], supercritical CO2 [9] and ionic liquids [10]. Recently, based on the critical solution temperature (CST) of temperature-dependent ligands in certain organic solvents, a biphasic catalysis system named “thermoregulated phase-separable catalysis (TPSC)” was proposed [11–13]. The character of this catalytic process was described as follows: the catalyst is immiscible with reaction media, but at the time the temperature exceeds the CST, it would thaw and form a homogeneous phase. After the completion of reaction, the mixture is cooled to a temperature lower than the CST. As a result, the catalyst would precipitate from the solution automatically. The TPSC process is characterized by homogeneous reaction and biphasic separation [14,15]. Ionic liquids (ILs), as environmental friendly reaction media or catalysts, have attracted increasing attention because of their excellent advantages such as negligible volatility, excellent thermal stability, remarkable solubility, and a variety of available structures [16–20]. Among the numerous ILs developed, recyclable ones were figured as the most important research targets. Unfortunately, ILs showed more or less solubility in commonly used molecular solvents, which caused inconvenience for product separation and catalyst recovery, especially in homogeneous catalysis. Recently, chemists developed some temperature driven reversible biphasic catalysis systems such as phase-transfer catalysis [21–23], thermoregulated phase-transfer catalysis [14,24–27], liquid–liquid biphasic catalysis [28,29] and PEG biphasic systems [30–35]. Some FBS like IL/organic systems were also developed. Examples of such ILs include fluorous-tagged ionic liquid [36], polyether-based ionic liquids [37–39], heteropolyanion-based acidic ILs [40] and quaternary ammonium-based ionic liquid [41]. In this paper, a series of poly(ethylene glycol) linked dicationic neutral ionic liquids (PEG-DILs) and poly(ethylene glycol) linked dicationic acidic ionic liquids (PEG-DAILs) were synthesized from cheaply available PEGs via a simple route (Schemes 1 and 2 ) and applied in acetalization and esterification. The effect of PEG chain length on the phase behavior of target ILs with molecular solvents was also investigated. As a result, all the ILs were found to have the temperature-dependent biphasic behavior with toluene in a certain degree. Among them, PEG-1000 based dicationic acidic ionic liquid (PEG1000-DAIL) and PEG-1000 based dicationic neutral ionic liquid (PEG1000-DIL) show the best results. Actually, the PEG1000-DAIL/toluene catalytic system was successfully used to synthesize 5-oxo-5,6,7,8-tetrahydro-4H-benzobpyrans in our previous work [42]. Very recently, we reported a tertiary amine functionalized poly(ethylene glycol) linked dicationic ionic liquid exhibiting thermoregulated reversible biphase behavior with cyclohexane/isopropanol and used it as high efficient and recyclable catalyst in Knoevenagel condensation [43]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All of the reagents and solvents are commercially available and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded in KBr disks with a Bomem MB154S FT-IR spectrometer. Mass spectra were taken on an Agilent LC-MS 1100 series instrument in the electrospray ionization (positive ESI) mode. GC analyses were performed on an Agilent 7890A instrument. 1H NMR and 13C NMR were recorded on Bruker DRX 500 and tetramethylsilane (TMS) was used as internal standard. 2.2 Procedure for the synthesis of PEG-DAIL Imidazole (0.5mol) and sodium ethoxide (0.5mol) were dissolved in ethanol (50mL), the solution was stirred at 70°C for 8h, then ethanol was removed by rotator evaporation under reduced pressure, the residue was washed with diethyl ether three times and dried in vacuum to give intermediate 1. Subsequently, intermediate 1 (0.5mol) and compound 2 (0.25mol, prepared by a reported method [42]) were dissolved in ethanol (50mL) and the mixture was heated to reflux and let react for 10h, the mixture was then filtered, the filtrate was washed by diethyl ether several times then evaporated under reduced pressure to give intermediate 3 as a colorless oil. 1,3-Propane sultone (1,3-PS) was added dropwise into the solution of intermediate 3 in toluene (30mL) within 30min, the mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 8h and evaporated under reduced pressure. Then the solution of H2SO4 in ethanol (30mL) was added dropwise within 30min. The final solution was stirred at 50°C for another 8h and evaporated under reduced pressure to give PEG-DAIL 4 as a viscous brown liquid. The reaction mixture was stirred thoroughly at 80°C for 1h. After the completion of reaction, the mixture separated into two phases at room temperature, the upper phase was decanted for analysis and the below phase was reused for the next time directly or after removing water under vacuum at 80°C for 1h. 2.5 General procedure for acetalization in PEG1000-DAIL/toluene system Aromatic aldehydes (2mmol) and alcohols (3mmol) were added into a 10mL tube reactor preloaded with PEG1000-DAIL (2mL) and toluene (2mL). The reacution mixtre was stirred at 80°C for 1h. After the reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and the mixture separated into two phases. After decantation of the upper phase, the below phase was reused for the next time after removing water under vacuum at 80°C for 1h. 2.6 General procedure for acetalization in PEG1000-DIL/toluene/PTSA system Aromatic aldehydes (2mmol), ethylene glycol (3mmol) and para-toluenesulfonic acid (3mmol) were added into a 10mL tube reactor preloaded with PEG1000-DIL (2mL) and toluene (2mL). The reaction mixture was stirred at 80°C for 4h, the mixture was then cooled to room temperature to let phase separation. After decantation of the upper phase, the below phase was reused for the next run after removing water under vacuum at 80°C for 1h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The solubility of PEG-DILs and PEG-DAILs in organic solvents The solubility of PEG-DILs and PEG-DAILs in organic solvents were tested at different temperatures. It was found that PEG-DILs and PEG-DAILs were soluble in water and some high polar solvents such as ethanol and nitrobenzene, but insoluble in less polar solvents such as diethyl ether, acetone, benzene, ethyl acetate and toluene at room temperature (Table 1 ). Among them, PEG1000-DIL and PEG1000-DAIL were soluble in toluene at higher temperatures (Table 2 , Entries 3 and 7), which ensures that the two can form a temperature-dependent biphasic system with toluene. The phase diagrams of PEG1000-D(A)IL/toluene systems were shown in Fig. 1 . The thermoregulated process of PEG1000-DAIL/toluene system was demonstrated in Fig. 2 . It was obvious from Fig. 2 that the phase separation was totally complete. The volume and color of toluene phase (upper layer) was unchanged. Actually, the quantitative test of the solubility of PEG1000-DAIL in toluene was done and found that the solubility was no more than 0.2wt% at 0°C and 0.6wt% at 20°C, in average of ten dissolution–separation cycles. In comparison, that of PEG1000-DIL was no more than 0.3wt% at 0°C and 0.9wt% at 20°C, furthermore, much longer time was required to ensure complete phase separation. Another most important point was that the mixture could form a homogeneous solution at 80°C since it was complete transparent and no micelle could be observed. 3.2 Esterification of aromatic acids in PEG1000-DAIL/toluene catalyst–medium system Esterification is one of the most traditional and basic reaction in synthetic chemistry and chemical engineering. It is also extensively employed for the protection of the carboxylic acids and alcohols [44,45]. Owing to the acidic nature of PEG1000-DAIL, esterification was chosen to evaluate the catalytic activity and recyclability of PEG1000-DAIL. Benzoic acid and ethanol were selected as the model substrates to optimize the reaction conditions. The results indicated that the yield ascended along with the increasing addition of ethanol. Esterification is a reversible reaction, so the excess of ethanol could make the equilibrium in favor of the ester formation. However, further increase of ethanol would reduced the yield, which might due to the slower reaction derived from reduced concentration of catalyst and acid (Table 3 , Entries 1–6). At the same time, 1h was enough to ensure the completion of reaction (Table 3, Entries 7–10). The recyclability of PEG1000-DAIL was further investigated by model esterification of benzoic acid and ethanol. As shown in Fig. 3 , the yield of ethyl benzoate decreased rapidly if PEG1000-DAIL was reused without any disposal. In comparison, the yield could still keep as high as 98% at the seventh cycle in case the water formed in last reaction was removed. Compared to the commonly used solvents and catalysts, the easy recycling performance and only 6% leaching of PEG1000-DAIL after seven times recycling are attractive merits. Then a variety of aromatic acids and alcohols were used and the results were presented in Table 4 . Excellent yields (85–99%) were obtained in all cases. But the selectivity was very sensitive to steric effect, which could be derived from the fact that linear alcohols afforded higher yields than branched ones (Table 4, Entries 1–14). Especially in the case of the one-step esterification of glycerol (Table 4, Entry 16), the yield (99%) of glycerol monobenzoate (7p) was unbelievably higher than traditional three-step route [46]. Some other aromatic acid such as o-phthalic acid, p-chlorobenzoic acid and p-nitrobenzoic acid reacted smoothly with ethanol to afford yields above 99% within 50min (Table 4, Entries 17–19). 3.3 Acetalization of aromatic aldehydes in PEG1000-DAIL/toluene catalyst–medium system Acetalization is one of the most commonly used methods for protection of aldehydes and diols in synthetic organic chemistry [47]. The product acetal is one of the important compounds for preparation of enantiomerically pure compounds which were widely used as fragrances, steroids and pharmaceuticals [48,49]. To further study the catalytic activity and recyclability of PEG1000-DAIL, the acetalization of 4-nitrobenzaldehyde and ethylene glycol was chosen as model reaction and the results were shown in Table 5 . Similar to the optimized conditions of esterification of benzoic acid and ethanol, molar ratio 1:1.5 of 4-nitrobenzaldehyde to glycol and 1h reaction time were the optimal choice. The reaction process of 4-nitrobenzaldehyde and ethylene glycol was demonstrated in Fig. 4 . The recycling experiments were done with 4-nitrobenzaldehyde and ethylene glycol and the results were similar to that of esterification as well (Fig. 5 ). The yield decreased dramatically if PEG1000-DAIL was reused directly and without any disposal. However, the yield could still keep as high as 96% at the seventh cycle in case the water was removed. Only a low catalyst leaking of 6% was observed. The substrate scope of acetalization was then examined using a variety of aromatic aldehydes and alcohols in PEG1000-DAIL/toluene system under the optimized condition and the results were listed in Table 6 . All aromatic aldehydes, no matter bearing electron withdrawing or donating substituent groups in aromatic ring, gave corresponding acetals solely. However, m-substituted aromatic aldehydes afforded lower yields than o- and p-substituted ones due to electronic effect. When ethylene glycol was used, the desired cyclic acetals were obtained in excellent yields within short times (Table 6, Entries 1–12), while ethanol required longer times (Table 6, Entries 13–24). The reason may be that five-member cyclic aromatic aldehydes ethylene glycol acetals were more stable than open ethanol acetals. 3.4 Acetalization in PEG1000-DIL/toluene/PTSA system When neutral PEG1000-DIL was used to replace acidic PEG1000-DAIL, acidic catalyst was required. In this work, para-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA) was applied to catalyze the acetalization. Benzaldehyde and ethylene glycol were used as model substrates. The yield was up to 91% when 1.5 equivalence of PTSA was added and reacted for 4h, while no product detected without PTSA. The recyclability of this catalytic system was also investigated to find that PEG1000-DIL/PTSA could be reused for seven times with only 3% loss of yield, which might owing to the dominated solubility of PTSA in PEG1000-DIL against toluene. A variety of aromatic aldehydes were then used in this thermoregulated biphasic catalytic system under the optimized condition and the results were listed in Table 7 . The affecting tendency of electric and steric effects reproduced that of PEG1000-DAIL/toluene system, but the yields were inevitably lower. 4 Conclusions In summary, a facile and efficient protocol for esterification and acetalization of aromatic acids and aldehydes in PEG1000-D(A)IL/toluene temperature-dependent biphasic system was developed. This kind of catalyst and reaction medium combined system is characteristic of temperature-dependent reversible biphasic property, simple and facile recyclability, high catalytic activity and extensive substrate and reaction adaptability. coredata.dc:description: A novel efficient and recyclable temperature-dependent biphasic catalyst and reaction media combined system comprised of PEG-1000 linked dicationic acidic ionic liquid and toluene was developed and applied in esterification of aromatic acids and acetalization of aromatic aldehydes with good to excellent yields. This system is characteristic of temperature-dependent reversible biphasic property, simple and facile recyclability, high catalytic activity and extensive substrate and reaction adaptability.
coredata.dc:title: A facile and efficient protocol for esterification and acetalization in a PEG1000-D(A)IL/toluene thermoregulated catalyst–media combined systems
